topic: Deep dive: smtplib standard library module in Python 3.12+
prompt: Write a Python 3.12+ focused, accurate explainer for: Deep dive: smtplib standard library module in Python 3.12+

response_parsed.title: Deep Dive: smtplib Standard Library Module in Python 3.12+
response_parsed.summary: This explainer provides an in-depth look at the smtplib module in Python 3.12+, which is used for sending emails from a Python script.
key_points: smtplib allows Python scripts to send emails using SMTP protocol
Supports SSL/TLS encryption for secure communication
Provides methods for sending simple text emails and complex HTML emails
Supports authentication for sending emails from mail servers that require it

code_examples.code:
import smtplib

sender = smtplib.SMTP('smtp.gmail.com', 587)
sender.starttls()
sender.login(user, password)
sender.sendmail(sender, receiver, message)
sender.quit()

from email.mime.text import MIMEText

msg = MIMEText('Hello, World!', 'plain')
msg['Subject'] = 'Test Email'
msg['From'] = user
msg['To'] = receiver
smtplib.sendmail(user, receiver, msg.as_string())

version_notes: Python 3.12+ is required for improved SMTP support and TLS/SSL encryption
Pre-3.12 versions may not provide these enhancements
caveats: You must replace 'user' and 'password' with your Gmail credentials
Replace 'smtp.gmail.com', '587', 'user', 'receiver' with appropriate values for other email providers
Be mindful of spamming rules when sending bulk emails
